content.div:
Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn — Part 1: Three stars out of five — Like all fine cheeses, The Twilight Saga ripens with age. Once bland and milky-white, the story of Bella Swan’s transformation from innocence to adulthood grows increasingly textured with each new outing. This latest effort is easily the strongest to date, as director Bill Condon finds a way to lighten the melodrama with a little self-winking humour, without eroding the romantic core of the whole franchise. This is the instalment every Twihard was waiting for, as it features the physical consummation of Bella (Kristen Stewart) and Edward’s (Robert Pattinson) love. This symbolic and physical deflowering of Bella is the central hook for this whole episode, and Condon has to take us into the breathless, heart-thumping world of a virgin facing the cliff of experience — and leaping into the abyss. With the help of Stewart’s strongest performance to date, Condon successfully conveys the depth of connection between the two lovers. We believe in their passion, and, once we’re on that page, we can swallow the rest of the plot without choking on the hokum. Special features include six-part behind-the-scenes documentary, Bella and Edward’s wedding video, Jacob’s Destiny, Edward Fast Forward, Jacob Fast Forward, audio commentary and more. (Released Feb. 11).

Frank Capra: A World at War: Four stars out of five — Although this will probably only be of interest to anyone who’s a diehard Frank Capra fan, it doesn’t mean these classic pieces of war propaganda won’t appeal to a wide variety of viewers, especially the modern marketer or war buff. Personally assigned to sell war to the American masses by Chief of Staff George C. Marshall, Capra embarked on the Why We Fight Series. He made seven reels, including the four included on this first-ever take-home package: Prelude to War, Divide and Conquer, The Battle for China, and The Battle for Russia. Walt Disney helped with the animated sequences, and it soon became clear these well-produced, fact-based pieces were doing their job. America was motivated and engaged in the battle to liberate Europe, and even Winston Churchill realized their power, ordering them to be shown in theatres across Britain. Prelude to War even won the Academy Award for best documentary, but the real bonus was what it did for Capra: It solidified the American Dream in his own mind, paving the way for postwar classics such as It’s a Wonderful Life. Special features include digital transfer and more.

La jetee/ Sans Soleil: Four stars out of five — Celebrate, cinephiles, because you’ve no doubt been waiting for this day for quite some time. So jump around in that black turtleneck and clean those tortoise-rim glasses, because Chris Marker’s La jetee is now available as a Blu-ray disc. That means you can treat all your friends to this masterpiece of short filmmaking, which is essentially a montage of still images — with a few brilliant moments of motion. Classified as science fiction, this iconic fragment of the French New Wave is considered important for its breakdown of perception, place and identity via the camera itself. Confusing us with its mixture of still and moving pictures, the 20-minute short launches us into an alternative mode of seeing, which is eventually reflected in the moving image of a woman opening her eyes. Sure, you could call it pompous and pretentious, but that will never take away from Marker’s place in the annals of film as an experimenter and adventurer. The bonus movie here is Sans Soleil, one of Marker’s later works inspired by the music of Modest Mussorgsky.

Anonymous: Three stars out of five — The biggest surprise here isn’t that William Shakespeare may be a complete fraud who was given credit for work he did not write, but the name on the director’s chair: Roland Emmerich, the man who made Independence Day and other pyrotechnical spectacles. Here, the king of Saturday-morning sugar cereal tries to elevate his base station by taking on a period tale of intellectual property, complete with a fancy-pants cast that includes Vanessa Redgrave, Rhys Ifans, Joely Richardson and Derek Jacobi. It looks fantastic, and it talks even better, but the very idea that Shakespeare was an illiterate boob who bumbled into the greatest written works of the English language is still a tad unpalatable. Emmerich seems a little drunk on the sepia-toned earnestness of his tale, and drains the story of natural tension, but he does give us great lines such as, “Since when did words ever win a kingdom? I think I shall keep my sword.” It’s these little nods and curtsies that make it fun, even when the narrative gets lost in literary history. Special features include commentary with Roland Emmerich and writer John Orloff, deleted scenes, and Who Is the Real William Shakespeare?

Downton Abbey, Season Two: Four stars out of five — An update on the Upstairs Downstairs idea, Downton Abbey tells the story of the Granthams, as they keep calm and carry on at the start of the great war. A complex hive of narrative that includes everything from blackmail to betrayal, the stories are epic, but the delivery is always human, thanks to the solid cast lead by Dame Maggie Smith, as well as Elizabeth McGovern, Michelle Dockery and Dan Stevens. If you’ve never seen an episode, you can sample the goods before purchase by watching two complete instalments at pbs.org. Special features on this take-home disc version include spotlights on Fashion and Uniforms, Romance in a Time of War, and House to Hospital.

Also released Feb. 7:

Code Geass: Lelouch of the Rebellion

CSI: Grave Danger

Cyberbully

Dreamgirls

Father Dowling Mysteries

Fish Called Wanda (Blu-ray)

Get Shorty (Blu-ray)

The Hour

Lady and the Tramp, Diamond Edition

Lindsay Buckingham with Special Guest Stevie Nicks

Love Story

Mayday!

Meowingtons Hax 2K11 Toronto

Mickey Mouse Clubhouse I Heart Minnie

Night of the Dead

Phantom of the Opera at Royal Albert Hall

The Piano

Police Woman, Season 2

Porn Star Zombies

Robot Chicken: Star Wars III

A Very Harold and Kumar Christmas

Wiggles: Wiggletime

Twitter.com/katherinemonk

link.Abstract: Stewart offers up a standout performance as she finally gets some dramatic flesh to sink her teeth into, while Pattinson almost feels warm, despite his character’s icy skin. This may be the best Twilight yet.

link.Abstract: Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart continue their love story in The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1.

link.Abstract: Kristen Stewart, Robert Pattinson, Taylor Lautner and throngs of excited Twi-Hards turn out for the Los Angeles premiere of Breaking Dawn Pt. 1 and ET Canada's Matte Babel is in the middle of it all.

link.Abstract: A juicy first look at 'Breaking Dawn'. Bella and Edward exchange vows, and baby bump follows. But their unborn child threatens the wolf pack and vampire coven for different reasons.

link.Abstract: The actress talks about abandoning Bella for Snow White.

link.Abstract: Pop Forecast is for a hot and heavy Twilight. We also send An Idiot Abroad and mark Drake’s return.

entry.title: The lowdown on Downton Abbey

link.Abstract: Praise the lord of the manor and pass the smelling salts: Downton Abbey is on its way back to PBS.

link.Abstract: Downton Abbey's Maggie Smith is nominated for a Golden Globe this year. The PBS period drama is up for four Golden Globes, to be awarded Jan. 15.
link.title: Downton Abbey

link.Abstract: The Artist, a black-and-white silent film about Hollywood, drama The Descendants, Brad Pitt, Martin Scorsese and Terrence Malick all won big on Sunday among U.S. film critics and industry groups that doled out honors for the year's best movies.
link.title: The Artist, Descendants lead critics awards

link.Abstract: Mad Men made history Sunday at the 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards in Los Angeles - history both good and not-so-good.
link.title: Emmys keep winners in the family

link.Abstract: The Avengers assemble, Mad Men makes March, Bond is back and Leonard Cohen is still The Man.
link.title: 2012's Pop Forecast
